reviews: Trüb bernsteinfarben mit weißer Schaumkrone. Malziger, hopfiger, eher leicht fruchtiger Geruch. Geschmacklich betont bitter malzig mit Citrus, Grapefruit und Anklängen an Karamell. Mittlere Süße mit hoher Bitterkeit, mittlerer Körper mit spürbarer Kohlensäure.

Blik 35,5cl thuis gedeeld als Celebration Fresh Hop IPA. Pine, citrus, malten, licht plakkerig, tropisch fruit, bitter, bloemig, hop (cascade, centennial, chinook), caramel. English Strong Ale invloeden. (27-3-2022).

Pours a deep amber colour with a pale tan-coloured head.  The aroma is grassy and slightly of cough mixture.  The taste is initially sweet with a moderate bitterness kicking in afterwards.  Overall a good quality beer.

Can from Drankenhandel Leiden. Aroma is piney hop with grapefruit, malt, pine resin, orange. Hint of caramel. Bitter flavour with some sweetness. Medium body. Bitter, piney and malty. First brewed in the year of my birth, gotta respect the classics.

Flasche 0,355l: Dunkles Bernstein, Kupfer, leichte Trübung, stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; sehr fruchtige + würzige Nase, leichte Süße, kräftige frische Hopfenaromen, leichte Zitrusnoten, dunkle/reife Früchte, kräftig Malz, Getreide, leichte Röstaromen, kräftige Hefearomen, fruchtig-würzige Bitterkeit; fruchtiger + würziger Körper, kräftige Süße, würzige Hopfenaromen, Zitrusnoten, leichte trockene Säure, dunkle/getrocknete Früchte, kräurige Noten, etwas Pinie, kräftig Malz, Getreide, Karamell, cremig, deutliche Kohlensäure, kräftige Hefearomen; fruchtig-würziger Nachgang

12 oz can pours an almost clear copper color with lots of bubbles rising to a decent sized off-white head that both lasts and leaves some lacing.  Aroma has pine resin, grapefruit, and caramel.  Taste is definitely bitter.  Body is medium to full with average carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel.  Aptly named, this is one to celebrate.

2021 can. Somewhat hazy dark amber pour with a big sudsy off-white head that has great retention and lots of sticky lacing. The aroma is rather piney with lots pine needles, twigs, and rye breads. The taste is bitter hops forward with lots of pine, grapefruit, orange peel and some caramel. Finishes long and bittersweet, Overall ;top shelf baby

On tap at Melos pizza Danville Ca. 2021 Celebration “Fresh Hop” IPA much better than years past to my taste. Much more hoppy than malty for a Holiday brew…as the name suggests! Smooth wet finish that you could still enjoy by the old Yule Log too!

Robe ambrée rousse avec une mousse assez très légère et fine
Senteurs sur le caramel, le pin, les fruits rouges et de baies de sureau.
Première bouche surprenante dans sa forme, très discrète au début puis avec une amertume qui monte crescendo, des arômes de caramel, de citra et de raisins se distinguent et une belle finesse émerge de l'ensemble. On distingue aussi des sursauts de menthe et de thym faiblement perceptibles.
Des arômes de pin et de pamplemousse et une belle rondeur houblonnée de fin de bouche terminent la gorgée, une belle amertume étrangement bien équilibrée entre la rondeur la finale sèche, Sierra Nevada confirme une nouvelle fois sa maîtrise du sujet et réalise une IPA complexe et accessible, preuve de son savoir faire.
Merci à cette brasserie de nous proposer de belles découvertes !
Bottle of 33cl. Pours ruby/amber. Aroma is mostly grapefruit and pinewood. Finish is dry with mid/high bitterness

335 ml bottle poured in to a Tulip. Dark copper colour with a creamy off-white head. Fruity aroma with citrus, caramel malts, pines, floral hoppy notes. Taste is bitter. Medium bodied. Dry and bitter finish with pines and citrus accents. Nice West Coast IPA.
Amber color without head. Malt, some caramel, brown sugar and hop aromas. Dry taste.
Plutôt rousse, mousse assez dense et fine. Pas mal de corps, caramel, houblons américains cascade, centennial, chinook (pas ceux que je préfére). Assez sympa.

355ml 2020 bottle. Pours unclear amber with a big foamy head. A lot of caramel, grapefruit zest, pine, tangerine, nuts, herbal hops. Hoppy bitterness, malty caramelly sweetness. Full bodied, oily texture, lively to soft carbonated, dry hoppy bittersweet finish. Nice classic IPA!

Bottle. Clear dark orange/amber sporting a decent firm white head. Aroma of citrus fruits, resin and pine. Taste is all that plus a solid   malt base, some grass and caramel topped off with a herbal bitterness that keeps lingering on till the cows come home. Medium carbonation. Very balanced. Really good.

12-02-2021; bottle; at home (bought at Saveur Bière, as part of their January 2021 discovery box).
The beer looks very nice. The colour is a nice golden amber, witha a lovely bright glow. The beer is absolutely crystal clear. Some nice fine bubbles can be seen rising towards the top. There they form a very nice silky smooth light grayish brown layer of foam. Foam retention is good and a decent drape is left on top of the beer. All in all, looking very good. 
The aroma of the beer is nice. Malts form a nice bismuth base, with some notes of caramel and a touch of bread. Hops are nice and robust. They give strong aromas of pine, some nice resin and also nice zest, stone fruit, citrus. It is quite a hoppy beer, and definitely New World hops. Also some great spicy hop notes, giving it some holiday flare. There is some alcohol in there too. Nice aromas. 
The taste of the beer is good. Bitter hops, some nice acidity from the hops too, and nice sweet malts. The result is a pretty well balanced beer.
The palate of the beer is also good. Medium body, slightly sticky texture and nice medium carbonation. The finish of the beer is nice and has nice bitter hops, with quite some nice zesty notes and some pine. All in all, a great IPA with New World hops. Reason for a celebration alright.

2020 Celebration: Ein kupferfarbenes Ale im Glas mit leicht hellbraunem Schaum. In der Nase Malz und leichte Haselnußtöne. Im Mund deutlich bitter und dazu malzig, außerdem etwas Blutorange und wieder nussige Aromen.

Bottle from Systembolaget. The heavy treacle like malts and nicely balanced by the hops. Dark amber colour. Just as in the aroma, it is a very well balanced beefy West coast ipa with a sort of English strong ale. It works rather nicely to be honest.  (7/2/21)
Same conditions rerate. 3.5 to 3.6 came across as more mature ipa, very nice.

Bottle from an online shop, drunk while Vietnamese take out is being picked up, yum. Thank goodness the Sierra Nevada cap reminded me to use a bottle opener; I've hardly any teeth left, from all the beers that forgot to mention this. Color is deep amber with a big cream colored head. Faint nose of citrus and caramel. The flavor has a lot of caramel, wow, wasn't expecting that. Bitterness is very present, the grapefruity not-so-pleasant variety that's the reason I don't favor Sierra beers. Definitely a powerful older-style USA IPA, I guess a lot of Cascade and C hops. On style, but just not my cup of pale.

Bottle, 0.355l. Hazy amber/copper pour, one finger frothy off-white head. Good retention, lasting head, nice lacing on the glass. Interesting on the nose, citruses, ripe fruits, herbal and floral notes.

Medium body, average carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel and texture, chewy, slightly creamy, very nice on palate. Malty sweet taste combined with strong herbal bitter kick. Aroma of caramel malt, ripe fruits, candy. Toasty notes, grassy, herbs and spices, peppery. Strong lingering bitterness. Nicely balanced. Medium lasting finish, dry, bitter, lingering spiciness.

Good one.
Een mooi gebrouwen IPA. Ziet er schitterend uit. De geur is niet al te sterk. De smaak is heerlijk bitter zonder zo'n vervelende hopburn.

Dark amber colour, creamy head.
Aroma: caramel, citrus, malt, raisins, plums, apricot, some cream, fermented fruits, brown sugar. 
Taste: malt, caramel, yeast, brown sugar, bitter malt. Hint of molasses and spices. Dry finish.
35.5cl fles. Helder amber kleur, fijne romige creme schuimkraag. De geur is citrus en ananas. Smaak is zoet, citrus, karamel en ananas. Medium body en veel koolzuur

35,5 cl. bottle @ Rick.
Clear dark amber with an off-white head. Malty caramel aroma with some hops. Sweet taste with a long low-bitter finish. Very solid malty IPA.

2020
AR: Hopfen, Harz, Karamell, kräuterig, grasig, 
AP: trübes bernstein/kupfer
TA: Hopfen, bitter, kräuterig, grasig, Tabak, Karamell

12 ounce bottle at The Winking Lizard in Peninsula, Ohio. Scent of hops to the nose. Amber in color with a white head. Light taste of hops and sweetness. Well balanced and smooth. Little bit carbonated. Slight oily finish. Nice holiday beer. Cheers!

Bottle. 12 pack only $15.

Smells like sweetness.   It's yellow.

Tastes bitter and quenching. It's perfect.  Mouthfeel is easy and chuggable.

A perfect beer at a perfect price.

355 ml bottle, as 2019 Celebration Fresh Hop IPA. Amber colour, medium sized head mostly lasting, fair lacing, soft carbonation. Nose is hoppy, some strawberries and lemon, light pine, cereal malt. Flavour is moderate sweet, medium to intense bitterness, strong hops, grapefruit. Bone dry with a long lasting bitter finish. Pretty good!

Aroma: citric fruit, pine, some pineapple
Appearance: mildly hazy amber with a one-fingered beige head
Taste: citric fruit, pine, medium medium-high bitterness,
Palate: medium body, dry finish, medium-high carbonation
Overall:

A small bottle purchased locally in Vancouver from a private liquor store.

A copper colored beer with modest white head and a hoppy, malty nose, confirmed on the palate. Plenty of hops and malt goodness in the same glass. This is what I call a big IPA. Good stuff! ✌️😊
Some hops. Good palate. Not a fan of the hops but drinkable.........................

Colore ambrato con riflessi ramati, schiuma fine cremosa e persistente.Sentori di luppolo fresco, agrumi, frutti tropicali. Note dolciastre, agrumate, caramellate. Retrogusto amaro e speziato.
Bottiglia da 35,5 ml - 6,8 %
IPA India Pale Ale
If IPA could taste like snow on an evergreen...this is it. Nice pour, beautiful head. Fresh hop softened. Pair with chili, crab cakes, nachos....crisp refreshing..seasonal treat from Sierra

Copper, Bright, off-white Beerhead, with frothy, medium and lacing foam, Good retention. Intensive Hoppy flavors, such as Citrus, grapefruit, litchi. Slightly piney and spices. Typical American hops. Medium sweetness, High Bitterness, Soft carbonation, Smooth touch, The taste is mainly hoppy performances, like piney, citrusy, and also caramel malts, such as caramel, crusts, and little toasty. Overall, it's a complex beer and pretty enjoyable.

Beautiful soft copper poor with beige head. Malt aroma of pine and floral hops. Flavor is strong pine and floral hops that linger on the palate for hours. Finish is slightly candy sweet. This is ok, but I wouldn’t go out of my way to get it.
Rich copper color with lasting tan head.  Taste is strong bitter hops that lingers.  Slightly sweet malt at the end, but leans heavy to hops.

Butelka. Lekko mętnawe o miedzianym kolorze. Piana również prezentuje się świetnie,wysoka,biała,utrzymuje się długo. Owoce,i wyraźne szyszki w zapachu. W smaku podobnie z dużym naciskiem na chmielem,spora goryczka ,łagodzona trochę przez owoce. Wysycenie małe,lekko oleiste.Super..
It poured a 2” head, had a dark honey color and very mild citrus aroma. It’s a very drinkable, smooth beer but has a bit too much alcohol aftertaste for my liking.
Pours clear gold with a white rocky head; atoms of grapefruit and pine; crisp delightful palate with a zesty finish.
Found out of bottle. Pours a clear copper with medium foam that leaves a lot behind. Drinks like a smooth pale ale. Good winter option as it sits heavier than most for the style.

Color naranja oscuro, cercano al marrón, turbia, translúcida. Espuma beige de casi un dedo de espesor y corta retención. Aroma intenso a resina y pino, caramelo, miel y flores de lúpulo, ligeras notas cítricas. Sabor en esa línea más maltas tostadas y ligero café muy equilibrado, final medio corto cafetoso y seco, alcohol bien integrado. Textura acuosa. Carbonatación media.

Muy buena receta, limpia y equilibrada. Si ves llover por la ventana, mejor aún.

Classic winter brew. Floral hop notes and an amber hued pour. Complex sweet malts and hops (maple sweet and pine resin and citrus bite). Smooth finish that is not all bitter bite due to the sweet malt taste. Cheers!

Packaged on October 2018: bit old for the name 'Fresh hop IPA'
Very juicy and full-bodied, while not fruity. Good balance.

2018 edition, bottled in Oct 2018, so about 7 months old. 12 fl oz bottle, poured into a small tulip glass, where it appears a deep but clear amber shade, topped with a bog head of off white froth which is quite persistent. Aromas are muted floral hops, pine and resin, and a very malty presence. Taste is sweet malts to start off with, almost like a Belgian ale, followed by pine and resin bitter. Did someone say Xmas in a glass.  A mate of mine describes my Belgian Strong as that.
Celebration is something I always look for heading into Xmas.  Not easy to find in Aus, but was available in the last couple of years.  Best enjoyed with Family and Friends.

Bottle. Frothy, blooming tan head on an amber body. Grapefruit juice, berries, pine, grassy fresh hops, toast, light strawberry. Medium sweetness, tangy and tart, with slightly dusty, zesty medium bitterness. Slick medium body with natural carbonation and a deep, caramelic, hoppy and slightly dusty fresh hop feeling. Pretty solid. I don't like IPAs but the fresh hops helps. Appearance is lovely golden orange. Aroma and taste is lemon, grapefruit, and hops. Aftertaste is fairly bitter, but not so bitter that I wouldn't drink this at a get together.

Currently celebrating my birthday with the 2018 vintage of Sierra Nevada's Celebration IPA, although we're at around three months since bottling this still tastes fresh and flavorful! Poured into a snifter, this brew featured a long-lasting white foamy head atop a slightly hazy and murky amber-orange-red colored body, looks a bit raw but not unexpected for a beer meant to capture the rustic note of a fresh hop harvest. Aroma is surprisingly malty with strong notes of warm caramel and red fruit, along with some citrus hops in the background. The flavor follows with a hearty rich caramel malt baseline that segues into fruity esters and piney hops. Finishes with a pleasantly moderate piney bitterness that leaves an aftertaste of caramel and warm apple. Overall very enjoyable and refreshingly complex, yet another solid beer from Sierra Nevada that is good but not stand-out exceptional to me out of their line-up of good beers. In short, I would definitely drink this again, but wouldn't feel the need to grab it every year.
0,33 l bottle. Very good IPA in my mind but may be a little bit too bitter, but just a little bit :)

2018 edition - written "Fresh Hop IPA" (packaged 10/22/18). Unfiltered amber colour showing some very tiny particles, with a warm yellowish frothy top, good retention and lots of wavy lacing. Fruity malt aromas with roasted, caramel and nutty hints. The taste is floral, a little perfumy, with a nice dry end. Feels like a bigger, dry-hopped red ale. Quite nice !
Tap @ The Castle, Holland Park. Pours slightly hazy chestnut body with cream white head. Malts, caramel, citrus and some dark fruitiness. Refreshing!

Tap at the White Horse pub. Clear copper with loads of bubbles and a lively cream head. Strong resiny and grassy hops. Christmassy spices with pine resin, a hint of chocolate and dark malts and a sweet sticky finish. An interesting and slightly different take on a seasonal beer.

Bottle from 7-11. Copper coloured. Malty, pine hops, medium bodied. Fairly bitter. Pretty good.
Pours dark amber with a thick creme head. Aroma of hops and pine. Taste is typical of a pale ale with a significant amount of hops to grace the tastebuds. Palate includes more pine and resin.

Really not a Christmas beer, still it is one of the only beers I truly look forward too during the holidays, of course with the exception of the big boys that are released this time of year. Aroma is nice, noble hop, pine, resin, good malt characteristic. Appearance is reddish amber, nice off white head. Taste is typical pine, grass, dank, with a biscuit malt characteristic. Another IPA in the sheer endless range of IP variants California seems to have. I would call this one "Christmas IPA" Darker and Heavier in mouthfeel and spiciness from spices or hops (should ask the brewer which one)

Ultimate Christmas beer. Santa gets jealous of it because people start singing “Sierra Nevada Celebration Is Coming To Town”. Mrs Claus fantasizes about it  while diddling her cookie and Rudolph keeps it stashed in his cowboy flask on Xmas eve. Yuletide in a glass! Hohoho.
Smooth aroma,  smooth taste definitely a beer for a relaxing night on the couch, also beautiful citrus taste also aroma.

Quite possibly the best beer ever... perfectly balanced- big malt and fresh hop bite- not a malt monster not a hop bomb- not a imperial high alcohol double whatever- just a absolutely outstanding ale.

In other words this batch is better than last years.

Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale pours a hazy dark amber color with a beautiful and long-lasting off-white head and very nice lacing. Very pleasant floral notes from the hops dominate the bouquet with light orange peel and caramel notes from the malts. The caramel becomes more apparent upon taking a mouthful as it is the main component of the attack, a mid-palate of molasses, pine, flowers, and grapefruit follows and leads to a spicy, dry, and warming finish with strong, persistent bitterness with a hint of roastiness. The warming and dark character makes it a great choice for gloomy winter days, although when combined with its rather bright fruitiness, it makes one wonder where exactly this brew wants to be placed.

2010 Edition

This beer was served out of a 12oz. bottle dispensed into a glass....

Presentation - Label artwork is very tasteful and classy in the traditional SN style. Give one the feel of a sunny winter day. Always love SN bottles and artwork!

Appearance - SNCA pours out a orangish/copper color with a loose white head that sticks around and laces nicely down the glass.

Smell - This is def an IPA like it claims. I cold smell different hints of citrus and the classic IPA piney smell. Absolutely wonderful!!!

Taste - I want to start of by saying that I love IPAs so and this is one of the 3 best that I have had!!!! Taste goes along with the smell. Citrus/Piney taste throughout with a nice smooth bitterness on the backend.

Mouthfeel - A thinner light bodied beer which makes for a smooth feel in the mouth with a nice amount of carbonation that gives the feel of a more full bodied offering.

Drinkability - Very drinkable if you like IPAs. Smooth, tasty, and very enjoyable.

I really enjoyed this offerening because it was an IPA which is different from most holiday offerings. I would definitely recommend this to any IPA lover as a good holiday brew(Note: 2010 edition).



2011 Edition

This beer was served out of a 12oz. bottle dispensed into a glass....

Presentation - Same label and look of the 2010 edition only has 2011 stamped on it. Very nice.

Appearance - SNCA2011 pours out the same beautiful amber color with a light and airy 2 finger foam golden white foam head that slowly fades to a nice frothy coating.

Smell - Smells of strong floral/citrusy/piney hops. Some hints of bready malts as well. A very nice, big smell.

Taste - Tastes very piney on the front end before the floral/citrusy hop flavor takes over. In my opinion SNCA2011 was a bit more hopped than the 2010 edition.

Mouthfeel - Very nice amount of carbonation with a medium bodied feel. In my opinion SNCA2011 has a bit more body than the 2010 edition and has a slightly creamy feel.

Drinkability - Excellent taste and smell to go along with being medium bodied and moderately carbonated make this an extremely drinkable offering.

Celebration never disappoints. While the profile is slightly different from year to year it is always an exceptional brew!!



2012 Edition

Presentation: SNCA 2012 sports the same basic label artwork and setup as 2011 with the exception of the 2012 marking on the neck. Neck label gives a fine description of the beer and has the 2012 marking. Front label has the festive artwork in the traditional SN style. Rear label has a nice back story on the beer, ABV info, and website info.

Appearance: I poured this from its 12oz bottle into a 16oz English Pint. SNCA2012 pours out a clear copper orange color with a 2 finger white foam head of light density. Head retention is exceptional lasting a full 4min before fading to a thick coating and ring. Lacing was very good.

Smell/Aroma: Smells of fresh hops with a citrus and piney scent very prevalent. A slight caramel malt scent can be detected as well.

Flavor/Taste: Tastes follows the nose as the citrus and piney hops rule. A biscuit-like toasty malt flavor is detected on the front end that gives way to an intense hop bitterness on the finish. Very well balanced flavor profile.

MouthFeel/Drinkability: Medium bodied with a slick almost creamy mouthfeel. Above average amount of carbonation. Insanely drinkable with an excellent profile across the board.

Overall/Comments: SNCA is a completely different beer from nearly all that one will find offered in the winter seasonals. An excellent twist on the traditional classic American IPA. The fresher the better with SNCA. A true classic every year and SNCA2012 held true to form. Classified as an American IPA at 6.8% ABV. Consumed 1/11/13. 



2013 Edition

Presentation: Awesome label in the SNBC tradition that the festive SNCA feel with awesome eye-catching graphics and colors. Front label gives a bit of brewery info. Back label gives web info, ABV info, and a nice backstory on the beer. Neck label give vintage (2013) and a nice description of the beer.

Appearance: An aggressive pour from it 12oz brown bottle into a 16oz English pint led to a 3 finger white head of a medium rocky density atop a deep orange/copper/amber colored beer. Head retention was an awesome 5min 27 sec before fading to a thick coating and ring with phenomenal lacing. 

Smell/Aroma: Smell is of piney resin hops with nice herbal tone. Citrus aromas are very prevalent along with a nice caramel maltiness. 

Flavor/Taste: Tastes is of very piney resin on the front end with a sweet maltiness that balances out the resin very well. A sweet citrus hop flavor that blends nicely with a bready biscuit maltiness at the midpoint. Back end quickly turns pine hop bitter with a resin herbal aftertaste. 

MouthFeel/Drinkability: Medium bodied with a slick and creamy mouthfeel. The perfect amount of carbonation make this very drinkable. 

Overall/Comments: A truly great seasonal treat that I look forward to every year. The fresh hops are the star every year! A must drink! Consumed 1-21-14. Classified as an American IPA @ 6.8%ABV.
Bärnsten med stort ljust skum. Doft av tropiska toner och lite sötma. Söt fyllig öl med lång beska. Något dunkel och len,önskar lite mer crisp! Fortfarande god!

354 ml bottle at home. Pours a clear amber with an off-white head. The aroma is lightly hoppy with notes of pine, flowers and faint citric notes along with some biscuity malt. Medium to medium-full body with a medium bitterness and a very light sweetness. The flavor is medium hoppy with a distinct herbal bitterness along with blood oranges, grapefruits and some resinous and peppery notes with a discreet malt body in the back. Finishes with a good, hoppy (lightly metallic) bitterness. Built around the hop aroma yet not overly hop forward with a decent bitterness and good drinkability.

Pours copper red with medium white head. Aroma is hoppy, fruity, some hay, metallic, some fruit sweetness. Taste is fruity, fresh, hoppy, metallic, dry, hay. Very nice beer!
12oz can from Kroger (Staunton, VA).  Piney aromas, resiny, some grapefruit.  Clear amber with orange highlights, and a fully lasting off-white head.  Dry, citrusy, resinous.  Medium bodied.

Pours a cloudy, dark amber coloration with a large, fluffy, lasting head. Smells of biscuity, slightly grainy and caramelly malt and resinous, citrus hops, with notes of grapefruit and pine. Taste is an excellent balance of biscuity, caramel, slightly grainy malt and fruity, bitter and resinous hops, with notes of grapefruit, orange peel and pine, Finishes with a medium/strong bitterness and some grapefruit and pine lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.

This makes for a great old school IPA with a certain East Coast vibe, the bitter, resinous hops being balanced against a strong, slightly sweet malt backbone perfectly. The first time I had this it was over two years old and I was really impressed by how much resinous bitterness was still left in it, although the sweet malts had clearly taken over. Now, at four months old, those bitter, resinous hops and citrus notes clearly shine through a lot more distinctly, makinf for and even more enjoyable brew. There certainly is a reason that this is a classic and I really wish that I could get my hands on this even more fresh and regularly, although it really is a beer that keeps up incredibly well.

Keg at Rose and Thistle, Frimley. Not getting much aroma over food. Light chestnut. Creamy white head. Graduappy gains bitterness. At first had a caramel sweetness. Then hoppy bitterness gains prominence. Underlying malts. Medium bodied. Slick. Low key fizzy carb. Long finish with astringent bite. Not too bad. A malty IPA. Does leave a bad taste in the mouth I'm not entirely keen on. However works as a winter beer. 3.4

1/1/18
Had with Abby during the first quarter of Bama vs. Clemson sugar bowl. Roll Tide!!

Poured from bottle. Deep hazy orange with a 1 finger white head. 

Aroma is piney hops with a little sweetness. 

Taste is more piney hops with a fair caramel malt presence. Really well balanced. Both bitter and sweet. 

Not too much carbonation and medium feel. Hoppy bitterness lingers on the finish. 

Overall, this is awesome! Balance is exceptional! Lots of malty sweetness with a great showcase of the hops. Would have assumed it was a Double/Imperial from the malt presence. I’ll definitely get it next year too!

Update 11/11/2018 w/ the 2018 version.

Dense, floral and resinous with a fantastic balance of pine, citrus pith and a touch of malt. Killer IPA from Sierra Nevada!

4 finger off-white head.
Clear, amber coloured beer.


Aroma is grapefruit, lemon peels, apricot, caramel, light passionfruit and pine.


Taste is grapefruit, bready malts, pilsner spiciness and pepper with a boozy finish. Hint of clove and roasted malts.


Mouthfeel is semi-sticky with a slightly dry feel. Medium-high bitterness. Low carbonation.


Overall: An OK IPA with a good maltiness but it felt quite anonymous most of the time. Pleasant but not something I'm longing for to drink again.

An excellent winter time ale. Aroma is light pine a pinch of citrus and some roasty notes thrown in. Color is a medium brown to Amber. Flavor is a bit of pine with lots of rich caramel malt and toasted nuts, a medium bitter finish. Not too sweet and not fruity like a typical IPA. Just what I'm looking for in the winter to enjoy.
Orange gold pushing light  mahogany color  and light head.  Some pine and citrusy hop aromas and roasted malty balance. Medium body mouthfeel and true to style. Crisp  finish.

Celebration just made my Top 5 of any style. Pours a dark orange with a very thick, rocky, tan head which laces nicely and sticks around to the end. I like IPAs but was not sure if I would like fresh hops -- I do now! You get a tasty balance of hoppy bite and sweet malt delivered in medium body. If you like IPAs, but weren't sure if they were for winter --- this is your answer. It's delicious -- I normally don't buy beers twice because I like to keep trying new ones, but, I am definitely going to pick up another six for the holidays. Awesome.
Poured from bottle dated 9/28/17 copper color with a tan head. Aroma is doughy malt light citrus floral notes and pine. Taste is caramel spice and a strong lingering bitterness.

Pours a cloudy amber with a sudsy caramel colored head. Caramel malt and vegetal hop nose. Usual hop harshness from SN. 1) couldn’t believe I’d never had it; 2) went to one bar and three stores to finally find some; 3) regret that I got excited about it and paid $11+.

12floz bottle, BOD: 11.07.2017, $8 six-pack, pint glass. Appears amber in color with clarity and a beige sticky head. Very piney with an underlying note of caramel in both aroma and taste. Mostly bitter and body is on the heavier range of medium. I used to look forward to this more, but it's still a good beer.

Interesting, initial fruit then resinous, not malty, fresh and different. 
Hops and floral are not strong, but nice overall taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Taster in Salling. Pours amber with an off white head. Aroma of resin. Sweet caramel malts, grassy hops, citrus and grains. Taste is bitter with some sweet caramel malts, grassy hops, pine and citrus. Old and old school.
A rich powerful beer, full of hops and bursting with flavour. Perfect on a cold winters night
Gezapft. Leicht trübes Amber. Körperreich mit Wacholder Note. Saisonales IPA über die Wintermonate. Würde dieses mal zu einem würzigen Wildfleisch versuchen.
Pours a color of cognac, with plenty of head. Balanced taste of malt, hop, and pine. Malt in front, hoppy in back. Great with thanksgiving meal, terrible with cheese.

This is the 2017 release, labeled as Celebration Fresh Hop IPA. Piney-citrus nose with s some bubblegum esters as it warms up and breathes. Mid-malty body with, alas, a harsh bitterness that's roasty, rather than hoppy. Slight stickiness to the maltiness. Harsh bitter finish. A disappointment--this one didn't work for me.

Poured 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.
Appearance is burnt orange with a thin head and minimal lacing. Aroma consists of slightly piney hoppiness and malt. First sip is malty with some hops and spice and then finishes slightly bitter. This is a beer to which I look forward and thoroughly enjoy every year.
0,3 litre Bottle from Total Wine Boca Park. Cloudy Dark Golden with medium white head. Bitter.
This has been and continues to be one of my favorite beers. It never disappoints!

5 week old bottle > pilsner glass
A: Poured a thick pillow of craggy tan foam atop a dark tawny orange gold body with very good retention and busy carbonation visible.
S: Orange peel, pine and caramel. Amber-esque.
T: Bitter piney hops and lots of orange zest. Light citrus pith and dark bread or wood. 
M: Medium thick body and more carbonation than expected. Fairly clean finish with very little resin.
O: Thought this would be overly sweet but I don't get any extraneous spices etc. (fortunately). Been putting off trying it but found it pretty enjoyable.

(12oz bottle) AROMA: good hoppy nose, grapefruit, green, fresh, grass, pine, resin, some sour malt .... classic IPA nose. APPEARANCE: amber, brownish, very nice off-white head that is quite lingering and sticky TASTE: toasted malt, touch of coffee, woody, smokey, solid hops PALATE: medium body, good balance, crisp up front, oily middle, bitter followthru, OVERALL: very drinkable IPA with good body and balance, classic west-coast american IPA hoppiness but not overhopped. A rich and flavorful IPA that you could drink regularly.

ah it is finally celebration ale season again, the only good thing about daylight savings time. it has a nice hoppy resin pine smell with a red amber hue. It is a delectable balance of warming bitter hops and fruity malt backbone coming over on the aftertaste. One of my fave beers period and maybe my favorite sierra nevada one. Good for dashed 300 rise of an empire hopes with boo boo.

Dark copper appearance covered by off-white head. Rich hop and caramel malt aromas. Well balanced sweet hops and biscuity malt up front. Good body and mouth feel. Long finish with pleasant bitterness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The best APA that I have ever tasted. The barley malt to hops ratio is as close to perfection as I have ever experienced! If you haven't tried it, then you are in for a treat!
The 2017 Sierra Nevada celebration Ale does not disappoint. It features a great mouth feel and perfect blend of bitterness that makes this beer so great!  The people up in Chico do it right!

From Nov 2005

Poured from the bottle(room temp) with a nice head that dissipated fairly slowly into a fine broken layer in the center and a fine lacing around the edge of glass. The colour is a very attractive and clear reddish gold.

The smell is a strong hoppy-fruity aroma that is very inviting, so compelling.

The taste is very strong hops with grapefruit notes that jumps at you early then settles down a bit in the middle with some malt tones and returns with a very nice bitterness in the aftertaste.
Wow! This is one of my favourite brews of *any* style!

Optisch schonmal super, Schaum perlt noch derb hoch nach dem Einschenken. In der Nase malzig, fruchtig, grasig, grünhopfig eben. Im Trunk komplex, süffig, Keks, Malz, Frucht, dann bitter, ein bisschen Spekulatius, wie ein leichter Barleywine. Sehr lecker!

12oz bottle at home. Pours slightly hazed reddish amber with a sticky off-white head and good lacing. Great IPA character with grapefruit, orange, pine resin, caramel malts, lots of hops bitterness offset with semi-sweet caramel malt. Lively spicy hops finish. Delicious.
Bottle, UK import, source not recorded. Backlog entry. Entering my historic scores for US beers whilst visiting New York. No tasting notes kept, just rating.
Forgot to rate this one, been a while back. Just remembered it being very full body and strong. too strong for my meal really. Maybe by itself it would have been better.

Aroma fersken, humle, malt. Utseende halvmørk gylden med offwhite skum. Smak fersken, humle, noe alkoholsmak. Bra balanse på smak, god bitterhet, lang bitter ettersmak. Flaske på The Bishops Arms Luleå 35,5cl 6,8% BF290917

---

Hop malt caramel spice aroma. Murky red Amber colour good head and lacing. Caramel chocolate malt flavour. Smooth palate.

More of an earthy taste. Kind of a toffee taste. The hops are overpowering everything else. Expectations are misleading.

Reviewed - A Brew With You, Ep. 62

Originally rated on 1/18/2009. Had this one today at Opal Devines in Austin. Flavor of floral hops with a nice bitterness, with a decent malt backbone. Normally you wouldnt think of an ipa as a christmas brew but this is a pretty good beer no matter the season

355 ml bottle. Unclear reddish amber body with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma has malt, caramel, citric fruit and flowers. Flavor is sweet, smooth malt with some caramel, citric fruit, spices and moderate bitterness. Fine balanced body and long lasting, pleasant aftertaste. Not the most bitter IPA in the class, but sure a fine ale anyway, smooth, tasty and balanced.

Pours a beautiful copper amber color. Lots and lots and lots of head. Some black sediment at the bottom of the glass, it never was suspended, went straight to the bottom. Excellent lacing, excellent retention. WOW!!

Aroma is like sweaty socks...yeah. I’ll call that earthy hops. Light citrus and citrus rind. Some tropical fruit. Meh

Taste is pretty good. Malty, hoppy bitter. It’s more bitter, but it takes a few sips to really kick in. There’s some good tropical fruit salad stuff going on here. 

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, bitter, but takes a while to kick in. Oily. Lingering bitterness.

Overall, it’s pretty good. It’s somewhere between an IPA and a DIPA. The lacing and head retention on this are amazing, and it’s easy to look over some of its flaws because it does look so amazing. I acquired this through a trade, and it’s a shame. I’d like to have a couple more. I’d recommend it, and I’m thirsty for more.

Draft Half Pint at White Horse Old Ale Festival 2009, Parsons Green, London in Nov 2009 - Intense hoppy aroma and intense taste. Very Hoppy; resiny spicy peppery floral American hops. Very fruity; bitter oranges. Solid Malty base; caramel, toffee, hint of honey and almonds. Fruity sweetness leads to resiny hoppy bitterness. Very dry bitter hoppy finish. Lovely Beer! (2009-11)

On tap. Pours clouded dark copper, large tan sticky head. Aroma of pine, grapefruit, orange, cedar, dark fruit, roasted caramel malts. Taste of same with lots of roasted grain and grass to balance the quite bitter citrus, spicy hops.

Pours a dark copper color, with a foamy white head and ample lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, some malt, sweetness and bit of grain. Taste is citrus, pine needles, malt sweetness. Nice bitterness and a fairly dry finish. Medium body, creamy with a nice blend of citrus and malt character. Enjoyable beer

Tried once at a beer fest. This time was a single 12 oz. bottle. It is a gorgeous medium amber and a slender whitish head. It smells of malt and perhaps a slight citrus. It tastes better the more you have of it. Moderate hoppiness, bitter start and bitter finish. The 6.8% abv is well covered. Very decent, just that there are others that are better.

I am sampling the version from 2020, a year that many would rightfully say wasn't much of a celebration. This has been one of my favorite beers for many, many years. I anticipate the holidays every year for, among other things, this beer. I've posted reviews here every years since 2017. Every year I've given it a stellar rating because it's consistently good. This rating is a composite with others from the past three years. 12-ounce bottle pours a slightly hazy copper color, creating a two-finger, off-white creamy head with lots of clingy residual lacing. Aroma is hard to make out, but I detect the spicy hoppiness along with caramel-glazed popcorn. The flavor is stellar: I make out caramel, butter cookies, white pepper, candied blood orange, toast, pine resins, and a woody and smoky bitterness.The mouthfeel is medium. This is the perfectly balanced bittersweet brew -- not too astringently hoppy, not too cloyingly sweet.

Rich deep amber complexion. Almost looks like a marzen. Off white sticky head leaving plenty of lacing. The aroma is fantastic. On the palate, the raw hoppy character hits you first followed by a malty sweetness. I got a little lemon rind and pine. Creamy mouth feel with a dry finish. Outstanding winter IPA.
B+. Pours a murky copper color with white head. Well balanced and good flavor

Bottle pours a clear copper with a two-finger off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is sweet hop. Flavor is a decent standard hop and malt. Nothing really notable. Bitterness is mild and aftertaste is pleasant.

Bottle purchased at France 44 and consumed with blonderedhead. Served up in a tulip style glass. Nose is a pleasant hoppy citrus and pine combination. Leads one to believe it’s going to be very fresh. Pours a copper/amber hue. Taste is obviously hop forward like most Sierra Nevada offerings. A malty characteristic kicks things off with a caramel sweetness before giving way to a hop bomb. There is a resiny quality that comes heavily into play in its mouthfeel. Finish is aggressively hops and it lingers for quite awhile. Good overall and a quality choice as a winter seasonal.

Bottle. Pours a copper orange with a lasting foamy off white head. Aroma is of pine, grapefruit, orange, caramel. Taste is of pine, caramel, grapefruit, bread, hint of tropical fruits. Oily mouthfeel, soft to medium carbonation.

Flaska från SB. Bärnstensfärgad kulör med orangevitt skum. Doft av citrus och rostad malt. Halvsöt kropp med mediumbeska och lätt bitter avslutning. Smak av citrus, torkade aprikoser och rostad karramemalt.
Leicht trübes Bernstein mit reichlich Schaum. Malzig, etwas Karamell, leicht fruchtig, Grapefruit, etwas Kiefer, leicht bitter.

Bottle from Taniguchi. Pours bronze with a light beige head soapy like sea foam. Has a toasted malt aroma, floral hopping, pine, brown bread, light chocolate. Toasty flavour too, wheat crackers, light caramel, pine hops. Drinks wonderfully, creamy body with good carbonation, moderate bitterness, quite full. A no-nonsense beer that does what satisfying beer should - has all the parts to make it go down well.
Nothing says Christmas like a Sierra holiday brew. Definitely full of that IPA hop.
Bottle. Hazy reddish brownish color with minimum white head. Not much aroma, passionfruit, citrus, malts. Bubblegum. Light mouthfeel, small sweetness with kinda harsh bitterness in the back.
On tap at The Burger Bar. Pours a copper colour and is a dericous hop slap with a heap of pine and spice.
One of my favorite seasonal beers. Head takes forever to dissipate and from there it’s wonderful pine and resin hop flavors.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Pours a hazy copper with white head. Aroma of hops with a malt finish.
Bottle from systembolaget. Pours a amber colour beer with a medium head. Fruity and hoppy with tropical fruits and pine. Dry finish

This is a gorgeous looking beer. Clear amber with a fluffy cream colored head that lingers a long time. Aroma of pine and citrus hops. Flavor is hop bitterness balanced with malt that is significant but not too sweet. It’s well balanced. Hop bitterness in the finish with a bit of spiciness. Tremendous beer. I forgot how good this was.
35.5cl bottle, 2017 release. cloudy amber colour with a medium sized slightly dark white head. hops, malts, citrus, caramel, pine. high bitterness. medium carbonation.

Rich dark amber pour with beige cap that fades to a ring. Aroma is earthy hop, floral notes with a hint of pine and just-noticeable bready malt. Flavor follows identically as the well-balance ensemble of flavors meld with a slightly hop-forward advance throughout the sip. Super tasty, and very pleasant aftertaste. I usually have this each year and enjoy it, but don’t remember it being damn good.

Pours a clear coppery orange-red with an off white foamy head. Light aroma of pine and malts. Fairly smooth with a malt base and a slightly bitter but smooth finish. Flavors remind me of a lighter version of Weyerbacher Double Simcoe or Founders ReDankulous. Very enjoyable.
amber pour from bottle with decent foamy head. aromatics and flavors of spicy malts, citrus, pine, resin, and some earthiness. good medium body. goes down fairly easy and isn’t too filling.

I had it on tap. It pours amber with an off-white head and lacing. The aroma is piny hops and caramel. The taste is caramel malt, roasty, and hops. There’s a really nice balance here. This is very good.

balanced aroma that has both hop and malt aromas. amber and clear in color with a nice lasting head. Taste is beautifully balanced beginning with nice malty, slight roasty flavor, followed by nice hoppy finish.
Dark amber with slight haze and a white lacing head. Bold, piney fresh hop aroma. Malty character with a hoppy bitter finish.

Bottle pour into shaker pint glass from One Stop Market. Appearance is clear, reddish amber with massive sparkle, 1 1/2-finger width rocky, foamy beige head with good retention and light, sudsy lacing. Aroma is bready malt balanced with tropical fruit and light resin hops. Taste is sweet tropical fruit balanced with the bitter resin over caramel malt backbone. Palate is light-to-medium bodied with slick texture, average carbonation and bitter slightly dominating over sweet at the finish. Overall, a really attractive beer with more of an APA feel than IPA. Good.
Bitter IPA; good stuff. Nice thick head, lots of lace and a clear dark amber color. Fresh hop, malty aroma. Flavor’s like nose, much more bitter than sweet, very piney.

Cloudy, dark amber pour, with a thick brownish white head. Aroma is really nice, strong with pine and spiciness. A little bitter bite on the first sip. Solid IPA taste, with some of the peppery taste I smelled earlier coming through. A tad sour on the back end. I like it, but maybe a rung below some of my favorites.
12 oz. bottle. Poured amber, with a lasting off white head and good lacing. Aroma of pine, pine needles. Taste was medium bitter, piney hops, peppery.

Fresh. Bottled less than a month ago. Pours deep amber with slight hazyness and a perfect 3/4 inch off-white head with excellent retention. Lacing is also very good. Aromas are piney American hops with some spice and some herbal overtones. Earthy yeast and some fresh baked bread from the malt is also present. So drinkable. Medium/light body, resiny texture and crisp carbonation and just a slight astringency makes for great palate. Flavors are all a close to perfect balance of hop flavors, mild malt sweetness, and enough bitterness to qualify it as an IPA. Beer finishes dry with the hop IBUs making a late appearance.
This is an old-school IPA that contrasts with today’s IBU bombs and less bitter English IPAs. - So drinkable and a classic!

355ml bottle. Clear dark amber with nice off-white head. Malt, barley, spicy, bread and floral aroma. Taste is sweet at start with malty notes and it is followed by bitter notes. Overall, a tasty beer.

12 Oz bottle. Pours clear amber orange with a frothy brown head leaving huge lacing. Relatively mild aromas, orange, sugar malt, and some floral and piney hops. Medium sweet with floral and rasiny hops up front, long, piney hop linger. Medium-full body with a slick mouthfeel and average carbonation with cloying sugars. Overall, well balanced and drinkable, but nothing noteworthy.

On tap. Pours a dark copper color with bit of a foamy head and ample lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, some malt, sweetness and bit of grain. Taste of citrus, malt sweetness and bit of grain. Nice bitterness and a fairly dry finish. Medium body, creamy with a nice blend of citrus and malt character. Enjoyable beer
Sierra Nevada brews their Celebration even better than the year before. It’s a tribute to the Brewers did they get it right and you’re after year

355 ml, bottle conditioned. Very hazy, dark golden reddish amber, lots of powdery sediments, thick beige head, fantastic lacing, low carbonation. Not much hops to the nose, but great caramelly dark malts coming through. Mouthfeel is creamy, dry at the end. Taste is sweet, malty and somehow some dark fruits at the back.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep copper color with a dense, bubbly off white head. Heavy lacing. Aromas are pine, toffee, sourdough bread, and florals. Some earthiness, hop bitterness primarily in the finish, caramel, grapefruit, dried sweet fruits, and grass. Medium body, pretty fizzy.

Visual: Pours dark copper brown with a small dissipating head, ringed retention with almost a full layer, singular tight steady streams.



Nose: faint generic light citrus hop oils, faint barley malt. (lvl-2)-pungency



Attack: crisp bite, tingly-micro-fizzy



Mid-palate: toasted barley malt (lvl--sweetness), tangy-almost lemony citrus, medium bitterness



Finish: pine, dandelion, lingering bitter hops on the tongue.



Summary: Is this really a fresh hop IPA? I don’t get any green in the hops at all; The barley malt body is quite big and almost too aggressive without letting any fresh hop shine through. Overall it’s above average, but unstructured and incoherent at points. (10/31/16 Note: mine had a packaged date of 10/19/15 so that’s undoubtedly why I didn’t get fresh hop oils in it.)
Draught @ Elizabeth Station. Pours a clear amber. Nose of sweet grain and malts. Flavour is essentially bitter hops with a slight malt sweetness.
[backlog] 25-06-16 // bottle at Sixties, Mainz. Pours amber copper coloured. Sweet malty body, some barley. Some caramel. Then nice herbal bitter hops.
Bottle. Pours deep golden with an off-white head. Aroma of malt, bread, some herbs and floral notes. Flavor is sweet and malty with some bitterness, herbs and bread. Medium body, average carbonation.
Amber body, offwhite head. Aroma has caramel, malty bread, spices, some earthly notes, grapefruit. Flavour add dried fruits and some nuts.
Deep red with bubbly white head. Citrus, caramel and burnt sugar. Sweet, harsh tea and green finish. Overall: nope. Where’s the hops?
Mørk gylden med høyt hvitt skum. Aroma av humle og karamell. Smaker søt, så en vag bitterhet. Bær av noe slag? Medium konsistens.

Lukt: Citrus og karamell.

Utseende: Honning farge.

Skum/kullsyre: Dekkende skum.

Smak: Citrus og karamell.

Medium: Flaske@330ml, ABV@6,8%, Når@28.07.2016

On bottle from Vimonopolet Norway. Deep golden color, slightly hazy with good foam. Medium/high
Aroma intensity; hops, caramel, malt and some fruitiness . Medium body & complexity. Some immediate sweetness,
Ok bitterness - ends up a little
Bit too sweet. Very enjoyable
