Bottle. Hazy dark amber with nice lasting head. Aroma is caramalt, pine, floral and malt. Taste is much like the aroma but the malty parts stands out. For beeing a malty ipa I think its very good.
Dark orange color. Sweet caramel aromas, fruits and alcohol, some hops. Sweet bread taste, caramel, sugar and pine hops.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet’s BU. 2015 version, in other words, way too old... Pours close to clear copper. Medium sized, slightly orange head. Malt, orange and some metallic nose. Malt, herbs, some grapefruit, resin and pine flavour. Bitter. Medium, oily body, soft carbonation. Sadly, too old.
How : bottle Appearance : almost clear dark golden with a small white head. Aroma : caramel, dried fruits, citrus, spice, wood, spice, pine and grass. Palate : medium body, average carbonation.

Aroma: caramel, pine, some red berries.
Taste: moderate sweet and below moderate bitterness.
Flavour: candied fruits, hops, caramel.

Good.

Bottle poured into nosing glass, pours amber with thick white head. Nose is mango, Passion fruit typical westcoast style IPA lots of fruityness. Taste is intense bitter fruity slightly alcoholic. Finish is light fruity astringent with grassy subnotes... Good one!

Bottle, Nov 2015. Amber color with big head. Aroma is herbal hops, piney, resinous, toasty malts. Taste is the same, quite bitter, nice toasty malt body. Bittersweet finish. More English than I would have expected from an American Fresh Hop IPA... Okay though. Why is this still within its European best before date?

Das Celebration Fresh Hop IPA 2015 aus der Flasche vom Händler des Vertrauens. Fast kupferfarben mit massiver, nahezu undurchdringlicher Schaumkrone im Glas. Feine Pinien- und Zitrusaromen im Antrunk und auch später. Wenig Restbittre.

I took this for a wet hop ipa and drinking it just half changed my mind: aromas of ripe pineapple and a kind of wet hopped aspect to it, with its peppery and subtle honey notes. Taste brings more pineapple, honey and pepper. Very pronounced bitterness at the finish. Some alcohol fumes. Interesting flavour profile.
2015er edition. Fresh intense floral beginning. Lots of fruity hops. Grassy floral hops. Pine with a nice malty body. The aftertaste is floral malty smooth, great round with a moderate bitterness.
355ml bottle, 2015 at Beer Station, Xiamen. Pours hazy amber with a white head. Aroma of pine and resin. Bitter finish.

2015 version from bottle. Pours amber/copper with a stunning head, the bubbles were nearly hexagonal. Aroma features orange peel from the hops and this carries through to the palate. A very solid brew.

Slightly cloudy, red brown. Spices, pine resin. Bitter, sweet through the finish. Mid heavy body, mid carbonation. Well balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

24 December 2021. Opaque amber color with an off-white head. A nice Hoppy and malty balance. Piney. Citrus. Caramel.  Thank you Mr. Grossman I need to put this in my Christmas rotation. Rating 4.2. 

26 November 2020. Bottle. Amber color pour with a thick off-white head that left fair lacing. The hoppy aroma was floral and pine. The taste is mildly bitter. It is very good. Rating 3.9. 


April 10, 2016:  Draft in Growler. It poured an amber color with a thin white head and minimal lacing. The aroma was light floral hops. The taste was tropical fruit and some caramel malt. I kept the beer overnight in the growler so I will try this one again. Rating 3.4.

On tap @ Sur & Bitter, Sandnes. Pours dark golden, with a creamy, off white head. Aroma is hoppy tropical notes of mango, apricots, pineapples and oranges, floral notes and malty notes of bread and toffee. Creamy body, with average carbonation. Flavour is bitter hops, with pine, orange peel and tropical notes of mango, apricots and litchi, as well as malty notes of bread, caramel and honey. Sweet, hoppy finish.
Homályos sötét borostyán szín, közepes, tartós hab. Illata enyhe, ipás. Kellemesen kesernyés, lágy ipás ízvilág, nem túl sok gyantával. Utóíze keserű, enyhe citrussal és gyantával. Közepesen testes.

Had this one a while back. Pours a bright orange and gold. Dank and heavy with tons of lacing and sticky head. Pine and grapefruit abound. Just so, so drinkable with moderate bitterness and mild sweet malts. Holy crap, so fresh and frutiy!

330ml bottle served in regular glass. Enjoyed in Hong Kong.
 
A: Pours a beautiful slightly cloudy amber color forming a big and creamy, light beige and soapy head with good retention. Forms tons of soapy and lingering lacings in the glass.

S: Caramel malts and fruits. Strong notes of grapefruit and orange zest. Hints of pine, honey, grass and pineapple. A bit boozy finish.

T: Slightly sweet upfront. Strong notes of caramel and grapefruit. Pine, honey, orange zest and grass. Great, intense and delicious bitterness.

M: Meidum body and carbonation. Great bittersweet balance. Grassy and pine persistent aftertaste.

O: Excellent drinkability. Excellent IPA. Sierra Nevada quality.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a clear orange-amber color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is a refreshing smell of pine. The taste is a great hop flavor. An excellent seasonal.
Very good IPA, goes perfect alone or with a good burger off the grill (not McDs or BK)

Hoppy and crash aroma, a dark nice colour 
Taste is full and round with a clear hop presence

Nice beer
Pours a very slightly hazy copper. Aroma is hoppy, but balanced. Slightly floral, pine and grass. Also some malt.

Bottle from Systembolaget, BB 25/10/2016. Amber appearance with a decent lasting foam. I quess this bottle hasn’t survived in the best way the trip overseas and then the Systembolagets way of keeping the beer, meaning that most of the aromas that should have been there has disappeared. Well, well, my nose can anyways feel som subtle piney aromas, not much citrus and that is pretty much it. Nice mouthfeel, well balanced with a lasting bitterness. A good and solid beer for the season.
@ Kristoffers väg 22/2-16. Bottle from Systembolaget. Fruity with malt, some hops, pine needles and caramel. Body is medium, the finish is dry and medium bitter. Probably been stored for too long.

12 oz bottle from De Bierkoning @ home, bottled 2 Oct. 2015, enjoyed 16 Feb. 2016 (had this before but looooooong ago). Clear, red/copper color. Nice big off white head with good lacing. Aroma’s: hops, bready malts, earthy. Retronasal it’s earthy bitter, fruity, light malty. Flavor us bitter with a moderate sweet backbone. Medium bodied. Long, dry and firm bitter finish. An American classic.
SB MoS , flaska. Frisk arom som klart överlevt Sauronbolagets hantering. Bärnstensfärg. Fin vardagsIPA om den nu fanns att tillgå.
Rejäl, smakfullt maltig, fin humlearom och balanserad beska. En bra öl helt enkelt!

Halvljus och grumlig. Trevlig frisk doft med fruktighet och lite tallbarr. Smaken är balanserad och trevlig lite för mycket beska för min smak

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 Fl oz bottle into shaker. Orange/copper beer with solid two finger head. Carbonation is constant and fine. Nose is subdued fruit toffees. Flat clean mouthfeel with aspirin bitter finish. Quite light and easy to drink, surprising given its ABV. Nice albeit one-dimensional. Of course it’s meant to be a Winter beer but here in Sydney it is 25 Celcius at 11pm so I’m drinking it straight out of the fridge. Probably better a little warmer.

Flaska från SB. Mörkorange klar vätska med högt gulbeiget skum. Frisk doft av citrus, koriander, örter, selleri, tuggummi, blommor, färskt gräs. Åt det sötare hållet med en del maltighet undertill. Medelstor kropp. Frisk beska från början. Något torr. Inte lika mycket fruktighet som i doften, mer aggressiv i humlen. Maltigheten drar åt pilsnerhållet. En ganska lätt öl, men samtidigt med bett i. Välhumlad och trevlig.
A: Amber coloured, huge off white head N: Floral, caramel, lots of hops, hint of liqourice T: Decent bitterness, quite deep wooden flavour. O: Lots more malty than expected. Still a good beer though.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into tulip glass

Appearance: pours a 3" pillowy off white head that falls very slowly and leaves abundant lacing behind. Color is cloudy reddish-amber.
Aroma: strong pine and citrus dominate but there is an evident malt in the background.
Mouthfeel: medium bodied, viscous and quite sticky with a quite dry finish.
Flavor: fine balance between the hop notes with a bready-sweet malt.
Overall: extremely well done. I am a rare IPA drinker but this one is definitely worth having.
Aromas of lemon rinds and caramel. Taste is lemon rind, red grapefruit, caramel malts, and some peppery biscuits.
Bottle into IPA glass. Pours a clear copper colour with off white head. Aroma is earthy and grassy. Taste is grassy hops with a nice maltiness to go with a pleasing bitterness. Good beer.

Poured from a bottle. Ruby mahagony Brown hue with medium vanilla head. Spicy malt flavor with citrus, pepper, and slight juniper. Like the subtle bitterness balanced with the malt. Still has a nice dry finish.

Sierra Nevada Hop Celebration 2015

This fresh hop winter IPA pours a deeper russet gold that kind of makes me think of Aki no Kimagure.

It’s got a great fragrant hop bouquet juicy fruits(mangoes & guava) with minty lemon as well.

Nice full body and very bitter hitting you with a pine whallop, then a hearty dose of fruits and finishing with a nod towards the malts. Even though it’s bitter it remains balanced good stuff.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33cl bottle
cloudy dark orange~brown colored
aroma full of hop, grass
taste malty, dry finish with less bitterness
drinkable IPA
Tap at Saddle & Sabre. Light copper color with white head. Leaves a lot of lacing. Slightly piney aroma and taste with caramel, grapefruit and floral notes. Well balanced, warming and quite pleasant.
12 ounce bottle. Strong hop aroma that changes as it warms. Starts out hoppy with citrus and pine, gets more earthy as it goes. Sweet flavor at first with a bitter finish that lingers.

A 12 fl oz bottle with a packaged date of 19th October 2015. Poured into a Spiegelau IPA glass. It poured a clear dark copper colour with a two finger cream coloured head that had great retention and left lots of nice lacing. Aromas are citrusy lemon, apple, piney hops and sweet but slight biscuit malts. There was also some herbal and spice here and there. Tastes of light citrus and hop bitterness before it kicks in with some strong maltiness and surprising booze but nice spice. Creamy, medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, this was definitely more malty and boozy than I expected (and not in a good way). However, I will retry this again to make sure, but at the moment, I definitely prefer Hop Hunter and Torpedo IPA over this.

Bottle 0.355l. Cloudy, orange to red colored. AROMA- honey sweet, red fruit and berries, strawberries, rowanberries. FLAVOR- slightly sweet with dry finish, bitter, red fruit and berries, needle-leaves. Lightly full bodied.
Very good.

#420
Bottle 0.355l as 2014 Celebration Fresh hop IPA. Copper-amber slightly hazy body, medium white head. Nice aroma of strawberries, rowanberries, honey, mango, red berries. Taste is bitter and sweet in balance, a bitvof tartness of berries. Rowanberries, cranberries, ground poppy seeds, hint of needle-leaves. Medium to full body, slightly carbonated. 
 Pleasantly balanced red IPA, really good one.

Poured a clear dark coppery colour with a two-finger off-white frothy head that retained very well and laced very well. Carbonation high and fine to medium. Aroma strongly of pine with a hint of citrus. Taste of sweet malt, strong pine and grapefruit. Medium body. Crisp and refreshing with a lingering strong bitterness on the finish. (labelled as 2105 Celebration).
Aroma is malt forward with some toffee and caramal. Taste has some herbal hops along with toffee. Nice
Complex taste with hint of bread and toast, reminds me of of taste of a porter. Full body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish. Overall quite nice but not my favorite.

Really enjoyed this one.  Dark copper appearance with big hop flavor balanced by malt sweetness.  Very good 

 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Deep orange brown color. 2-finger head upon pouring from a 12oz bottle. The head recedes a bit, but stays a bit foamy with the replenishing bubbles from below. This is fairly hazy as well.

It smells slightly tart and citrusy like from fruit and hops. There’s an earthy aroma that smells woodsy.

Kicks in with bitterness that is pretty powerful. It quickly moves to an earthy funk that you can’t quite describe. At first is seems like it has went bad as it is a strange and unexpected flavor. It fades rather quickly and kicks into sweet malty flavors. It starts to get bitter once again and the funk seems to come back. As the flavors fade, you are left with citrus / pine / bread and malt aftertastes.

Light side of medium on the mouth feel. Not thin and a bit slick. Stays fizzy which is quite nice.

Decent IPA. I believe that hops used for this (wild ones?) gives it the funky flavor. Tastes like they threw in the hops, the vines, roots, and dirt all in this one. Very earthy. It is ok to drink a few, but I don’t see myself buying a 6 pack or a 12 pack of it. Worth a try though.
Pours a copper from a bottle. Smells slightly of toffee, not much else in the nose. Flavor is very piney, some tropical notes, maltiness is nondeScript but present. Good beer.
Orange, disig med stort, fast skum. I doften finns tropiska frukter, aprikos och ananas. Stor fruktig smak med fin sötma som balanseras av en rejäl beska. De Klomp 2015-11-28
Very piney aroma and flavour, but manages to be refreshing. Very bitter. Decent full mouthfeel for a bottled beer.

Bottle. Pours a hazy copper colour with a light nose of hops, with a finely laced off-white, long lasting head. Good carbonation. Taste is bitterly hopped, grapefruit and pine. Oily mouthfeel, long finish.

Smells malty, hoppy, and sweet. Pours with a small head. Color is deep copper. I’m always happy to see this beer every year. One of my favorite offerings from Sierra Nevada. The taste is malty, hoppy, sweet. with a nice finish of bitter. Over all I really like it. I had this from a bottle.

12/24/15 Chicago (Pour from bottle into pint glass). 

Copper pour with off-white head, decent carbonation. Aroma of pine, malt and spice noted. Nice mix of malt and sweet taste, enjoyed the texture and felt good going down. Very good beer and I’m looking forward to more of these down the road.

Pours a clear dark golden with a small white head that leaves good lacing. Nose is of fruits and pine, pleasing. Taste is moderately bitter and lightly sweet with more fruity hops, caramel and cereals. Body is medium, carbonation too and mouthfeel is a bit oily. A bit old style but still really enjoyable. A fun hoppy beer, just what I needed! Merry Christmas people of RateBeer!
Bottle - pours deep amber with a white head. Caramel, pine, citrus and a bit of nutty malt. Taste is hop across the palate, but this is balanced with the malt. Palate is creamy with a bit of fizz.

Not the best notes as no internet access. Going from recall: Amber color with decent head. Piney, hop taste. Decent malt back bone. Not quite sure what was making it a holiday beer - was expecting some additional notes. Didn’t get that, but got a pretty solid dry-hopped IPA.
Amber color. Bubbly, white head. Nice aroma. Very hoppy with mostly pine and some citrus notes. Very well-balanced, and not overly-carbonated.

Pours a nice Amber color with a light brown head. Aroma is nice and not super strong but good. This is very full bodied and finishes pretty bitter. Mostly piney notes. A little more malty than some other IPAs. Nothing really Holiday about it, but a descent standard IPA!

Keg at The Font, Manchester. A hazy deep amber colour with a foamy off white head. Aroma of orange, pine, caramel, slight toasted malts, some wood and herbal hops. Taste of orange, slight grapefruit, a little raisin, resin, some nuttiness, slight wood, subtle pepper and earthy, herbal hops. Medium bodied, a slick texture and soft carbonation. A dry, lingering, resinous hop bitterness in the finish. Lots of citrus and resin in this beer, close to an imperial IPA in texture too. Well flavoured and boozy, I like the big, brash flavours but a little bit too hoppy, which I rarely say.

On draft at York River Landing. Another great beer from Sierra Nevada -- clear and red, with a lot of great hop aroma and flavor. Even though this is more malt forward than most IPAs, it doesn’t taste at all cloying or out of balance.

12oz brown bottle. 2015 bottling. Unfiltered deep golden appearance. The head is creamy and small, lots of lacing for those who like that kind of thing. Lovely hoppy nose featuring citrus/orange peel. Taste has mild sweet malts, hoppy notes of pine and citrus. Big hoppy aftertaste and bitterness, aftertaste is leafy and piney. Mouthfeel is medium with nice carbonation. A solid brew.

Murky dark brown colour. Frothy tan head, about an inch thick. Pleasant malty aroma, brown sugar, some caramel. Quite strong taste, bitter but not too sharp. Lots of barley. Has nice mouthfeel, soft and moderately thick. Good as an IPA, very well suited for the winter season.

Pours Amber, light white head. Aroma is caramel, faint pine and citrus. Taste is biscuit and caramel with pine and faint citrus hops. Moderate bitterness, medium body, fully carbonated. Not a bad beer!

Bottle from Premier, 2015. Pours coper with lots of frothy had and tons of lacing. Nose is maybe a hint of cinnamon and lots of grapefruit. Flavours of grapefruit, some pine, juicy fruit. Taste medium bitter, light sweet. Full sticky body with lively carbonation and lasting bitterness. Great!

Sampled on draught at The Tilted Kilt on S Wabash in Chicago. Orangey brown colour with a beige head. Bready aroma. The taste is very full and malty, with a strong flavour of orange zest and Seville orange marmalade with hints of pine and grapefruit skin. Excellent mouthfeel. This is a really first-class IPA.

Aroma is roasted malts, honey , caramel and clove. Taste is sweet malts and caramel. However the rich full hop provide is the star here. Rich clove, deep earthiness, and citrus here. Light tang but overall a well balanced and smooth execution. Appearance is a hazy amber with a thin pearl head that retains fairly well.

2015 vintage poured into a taster showing dried/tanned orange peel brown with sparse white foam on the top. 

The nose shows a strong background of sweet round malts with moderately intense notes of lemon and pineapple. 

The palate is medium bodied and well carbonated. The palate show a first impression and mid-palate of very light round sweet malts. The finish shows a sharp IPA bitterness. The linger shows hints of orange zest.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into an snifter. Pours a Amber orange color with a finger an a half of off white khaki head with a consistent flow of bubbles streaming from the bottom. Smells of pine, spice, floral, grapefruit and orange peel. 

Taste: very easy drinking for an almost 7% abv beer. has big notes of spice, floral and pine on the front end and is balanced out greatly by the citrus in the fresh cascade hops. The Carmel malty finish in this beer leaves your pallet begging for another sip. Awesome hop forward winter IPA.

Pours copper orange/amber with a medium khaki head. Head retention is ok. Lacing is minimal. AROMA: malty, herbal hops, peppercorn, grapefruit, citrus, pine resin, bubblegum, herbs, roasty, caramel, spices, slight cinnamon, coriander yeast esters, tropical fruits and black currants. TASTE: malt bitterness, hop spice, coriander, citrus, peppercorn, caramel, pine bitterness, cinnamon, earthy, boozy, biscuity, leaves, tropical fruits, brown sugar and molasses. AFTER TASTE: coriander, hop spice, malty and bittersweet citrus with an oily slightly thick spiced/bitter finish.

Appearance: clear pale amber with two fingers of rocky ivory head, good retention and moderate lacing. (4/5) Aroma: pine, citrus, floral, caramel. (8/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate-strong bitter. (8/10) Palate: medium body, moderate carbonation, off-dry lingering bitter finish. (4/5)

I’m a little baffled by what makes this a “holiday” beer. Don’t get me wrong: I don’t need an excuse to drink a good IPA, and this is in fact a good IPA. Actually, I did a little reading, and understand this is one of the first of the modern A/IPA’s, and could legitimately take the credit for spawning - or, at least, helping popularize - one of my favourite styles. But any spiciness in this is strictly hop-derived - there’s none of the “usual suspect” gingerbread spices usually associated with Wintereenmas here. Big bitter nicely balanced with pleasant caramel malts, and an off-dry lingering bitter finish. (16/20)

This IPA poured a beautiful amber colour with a quickly living, frothy, off white head. Scents include pepper, malt and hay. First swig was a little thin on the mouthfeel but robust on flavour. Spicy malts and lots of hop flavour most prominent. Finish is bitter with malty flavours lingering...

From bottle. Pours a copper color with a one-finger yellow head. Aroma and taste of pine and malts. Strong malt flavor, but bitter rather than sweet. I caught a fleeting taste of rose petal. Medium mouthfeel. Bitter finish.
Yum! Nice copper/amber pour with an off white head (into a Spiegelau IPA glass). Minor lacing. Nice burst of fresh floral hop bitterness with notes of pine and resin.
Strong balance of malt and hops. Holiday spice. Definitely a holiday type beers smooth and well made.

Growler pour into tulip glass smells of floral citrus and grapfruit.nice lasting head with lacings all around the glass.Taste is hoppy with medium body with a slight dry finish.Excellent example of a seasonal ipa!

Bottle from Albertsons. Surprised its taken me this long to get to this one. And a bit disappointing to boot. I guess was expecting a bit more from SN for a seasonal. A touch more bitterness and bite than the norm. Still good, but I was hoping for a bit more "Wow!"
Bottled. Has a nice dark brown. Has a wet hoppy taste. Not dry. It is tastes like a dark floral.. This is a excellent beer

Similar to torpedo but less intense pine aroma and taste, a little sweeter and malty as well. Mid palate very nice sweetness with medium bitterness. Very tasty beer for the winter months when want a milder and sweeter ipa. Pretty dry finish as well. Would buy again.

Updated review 11-2016: 
Subtle hop flavors and aromas, malts and bitterness up front and center. Pleasant sweetness. Very enjoyable

It pours a cooper color with slight hazing with a large off white head that leaves plenty of lacing. It has a malt aroma of nuts and caramel. The hops are piney and citrusy with floral being prominent. It has flavors of nuts and a hint of caramel with the pine and floral flavors taking over the majority of the flavor sensation. The are hints of dark fruits as well. It is meduim bodied in texture with a bitter knock on the palate that is long lasting, but enjoyable.

12 oz bottle, 2015 edition. 
 Amber with a tight, lasting tan head, and nice lace pattern. Fresh floral and pine aroma, combined with caramel and crystal malts. Flavor is sweet caramel malts, followed by spruce hops. lengthy bitter finish.

Nice aroma of fresh pine, some floral notes and a hint spice. Deep orange red color, with a huge tan head. Rich malt up front. Sweet. Caramel and fresh bread flavors. Huge richness in the malt. Bitterness cuts in nicely. Fresh pine and notes of pepper on the finish. Full rich mouth feel. Malt bill must be huge on this beer. Should be an everyday beer. Outstanding.
Pours amber, half finger of tan head. Aroma citrus, grassy, spruce. Taste is a mix of pine needle hops and sweet malt. A nice IPA.

12oz bottle pours clear toasted amber-red with 2 finger head. Nose is mango, fruity orange, melon, slighty sticky pine and citrus. Taste is crisp, round light-sweet toasted malt with orangey fruit and some grassy pine bitterness. Finishes with medium bitterness, citrus, melon, orange, toast.

Btl pours a slightly hazy Amber color with red highlights. Monsterous,billowy off white head lingers forever leaving huge puffs of lace clinging to glass. Aromas of fresh baked cookies,pine trees, and citrus notes. Tastes of sweet caramel, orange and resin. Medium body, soft mouthfeel, adequate carbonation and a nice mild bitter finish. I don’t know what it is about this beer but every year I try one bottle and end up going back to the store for a 12pk! Big malty backbone balanced with the fresh hop flavors and aromas make this beer perfect for the holidays. Get this beer right when it hits the shelves and you will understand why it has such a huge following.
IPA fresh hop style with a heavier malt backtone that makes it a bolder, cold-weather beer

Bottle from liquor store
nice copper color with nice white head
Excellent hop aroma with pine and citrus
Great lacing on the glass
Very good maltiness to balance the hops. 
Sierra Nevada yeast is very clean
A great beer.
Piney aroma. Clear darkish amber with a huge foamy off white head that lasts forever. Lots of malt. Lots of pine. A hint of sweet. Pretty good.

Bottle. Pours a hazy medium red/amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is of pine, malts and hops. Taste has a slight caramel sweetness to it while the malty flavour shines through. A lovely holiday season beer.

Excellent beer and even better IPA. For those of you spent on the current fascination with absurd amounts of citrus/grapefruit hop madness this is a welcome old friend. A far more balanced IPA with a full spectrum of hi’s, mids, and lows. Wish this was available year round!
Bottle, 2015 bottling. Sort of a ramped-up version of SNPA. Lots of stinging bitter piney hops set in a set in a rich malt base. Very tasty and satisfying.

Aroma has lots of malt for a SN beer, but still maintains their signature background of earthy piney hops. Beautiful medium amber color. Almost see through, but not quite with a fluffy cream colored head. The taste has pine hops that are subdued by the added malt, although there is not as much malt in the taste as there is in the aroma. Bitter and slightly sweet aftertaste that lingers for a while. Good slick palate, the carbonation is turned down a bit for this one. Overall this is a very enjoyable option from Sierra Nevada. A little too similar to several of their other IPA’s (I would like more creativity from a seasonal release), but I can’t really knock them for sticking with what works.
Amber. Kinda bitter. Super IPA/APA flight with John (Schlafly TIPA, Founders Harvest Ale, Pliny the Elder, Zombie Dust, Alpha King, Sierra Nevada Celebration ale)

This one is one of my favorites. I look forward to its arrival each year. There are slight variations from year to year but all are excellent. I also have a minor issue with it in the IPA category. It’s incredibly well balanced, loaded with taste, only mildly hop forward despite the generous fresh hopping. It’s piney, mildly citrusy, has a strong malt backbone which lands it in the low 60’s IBU’s despite being loaded with hops, and with a luscious consistency to the finish. It has the completeness of a beer which the brewer knows intimately.

Bottle. Hard to imagine that I haven’t rated this yet, given all the times I’ve had it. Colour...light amber with a thick ecru head. Nose...initially musty hops and then the hops be one bright and fresh with a piney lean. Palate...full, dry and earthy with tightly wound hops that ooze with piney goodness. The whole palate is dry and fairly lush with hop resin and the finish is brisk and lively.

Bottle @home. Pours amber cloudy/hazy with an off white head. Malty and caramel on the nose but then you get a big hop kick to the nose as well. Taste is a wee bit sweet which was a surprise with the hop nose also a bit thin, good but not great.

- N: Orange squash and pine/white pepper
- B: Sweet (caramel)
- F: A small sweet, butter-y biscuit on the way home
- Slightly fruitier and lighter than Torpedo Extra IPA.
Great hop aroma from Amber to light red pour fluffy head. Somewhat sweet and cloying from medium maltyness. Very heavy good for holidays as it says. One and done for a session.
One of my favorite brews. So big and complex, curious it is mentioned an IPA. So much more in malts here than a typical IPA. Biscuit and toast along with the big huge pine hops. Great complex finish.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; light copper pour with a creamy beige head, aroma has caramel plus some hints of pine, taste has caramel, mellow pine, some grapefruit, quite a bit of malt action, bitter finish.
Orange copper beer with white head. Heavy malty body with piney hop character. Bitter finish. Okay.

12oz bottle on 01/08/2015. Hazy reddish brown colour with a thickish beige coloured head. Sweet aroma of fruit, pine, spices and malt. Medium bodied and carbonation. Rich flavour, although a little on the sweet side of biscuit, malt, fruit and lots of hops. Nice bitter hoppy finish. A nice ale to sip.

Served on tap. Red Orange with a thick white head. Orange melon hops aroma. Medium heavy body. Malt hops citrus bitter flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Amber with off white head - Fruity hop aroma - Good malt body with some caramel notes with a good hop profile with fruity tones and hints of peppers - Fruity hop finish that has some pepper in the back - This was nice
Bottle shared at Black Swan, post CBC - fuzzy amber coloured pour with white head. Tropical and citrus fruity, hoppy and malty, some caramel, toffee, orange, pine, grapefruit, bitter finish. Decent.

Inget är som det borde. Jorden ruckas en aning ur sin bana för här här vi ett Sierra-öl som inte får hjärna och hjärta att slå frivolter av lycka. Men så har Sierra en helt egen måttstock som är lite mer kräset kalibrerad än alla andras. Det här kan med andra ord vara en braksucce, förklädd i en annan etikett.
Punertava väri, tiheä luonnonvalkea vaahto.Tuoksussa märkää nahkatakkia ja sitruksista humalaa. Maultaan maltainen, katkera ja täyteläinen. Tasapainoinen ja suutuntumaltaan virkistävä olut.
Bottle; pours cloudy amber with a khaki head; aroma is caramel, grapefruit, and malt; taste is malt, citrus, caramel, and a hint of spice; finish is bitter with some spice notes; nice IPA

On tap @GarricksHeadPub. Lots going on here, but it rounds out into a smooth, very palatable brew. Lighter and easier than I expected -- good balance of multiple hop strains that don’t overwhelm a solid malt base.
Bottle 2014 edition. Not as pungent as a torpedo but pretty fruity. Some distinctive Sierra Nevada tones filter through. A good drop.

Ett år gammal flaska. Mörkt bärnstensfärgad öl med inslag av rött. Ljusbeige skum. I doften finns storkaramelldoft, malt men även mycket humle, främst i form av tallbarr men även en del fruktighet som drar åt jordgubbe. Detta går igen i smaken. Bra humlebett trots att flaskan var ett år gammal.

T:
-starts with sweet malt and strawberries
-then huge resiny,piney notes
-orange,citrus,mango,peach take the backseat
-well carbonated
-finishes with grapefruit and a huge hoppy note
O:
nice, but too bitter for my tastes

Bottle.(2014 vintage)

Pours a nice dark amber.

Taste. Very bitter and very grapefruit forward, also with a slight pine and sweet caramel backing.

Overall. Very bitter and not for the feint hearted, whilst i think this is a very redeeming quality, this would get another couple of rating points if they kept or maybe even toned down the bitterness, to let the non bitter flavours of the hops present themselves better.
On tap. Light aroma and orange color. Medium cloudiness, slightly fruity start on this and a little bitterness on the finish. Weak. Really not a good beer.

Bottle from Total Wine, to Shaker.Appearance: orange/ red, persistent huge head. Aroma: cereal, conifer, floral. some fruit/spice.  Taste: Sweeter than the Torpedo, more malty, slight spice, plenty of bitterPalate: Medium body, bitter complex finish. Really good stuff.

Láhev 355 ml. Aroma je příjemně chlebové s jemným závanem zrajícího sýra. Pěna je zlato bílá, jemná, vysoká a držící. Barva samotného piva je sytě měděná a jemně kalná. V ústech pivo působí plně, má střední říz a je dobře pitelné. Jaká to lahodná IPA, opravdu velmi povedené pivo.

2016 Re-rate: Bottle from Val-U Liquor shared. Big, bold bready malt nose with some light grassy hops as it warms. Super-well balanced but definitely malt is the star on the palate. 330 ml bottle, packaged 17 October 2014 (so drinking at ~5 months of age). Pour is amber with thin white head. Hop aroma has pine, citrus orange/grapefruit, high bitterness, medium carbonation and a hint of alcohol warmth. Displays the same Sierra Nevada hop character you know and love.

Classic seasonal beer from this pioneer among American craft brewers. Egg-white, regular, medium thick, lacing, moussy head with excellent retention, over a deep orange amber robe with slow fizz, a bit hazy with some minute dark yeast bits floating around. Typical ’dank’ aroma of orange peel, pink grapefruit, pine needles, old cheese, bark, mango, roasted peanuts, sweet honey, warm butter, calvados, biscuit, sundried tomato, dry cookies. Fresh fruity onset, sweet orange, starfruit, pineapple and redcurrant, smooth with soft, supple mouthfeel, medium carbonation tingling a bit, very nutty, biscuity and toasted malt backbone providing support for a long, dry, resinous, peppery hop bitter finish, more earthy than citrussy (feeling almost ’English’), drying and cleansing the palate and very appetizing, with a malty ’juiciness’ underneath; dustier, more powdery and more ’basic’ bitter after adding the deposit. Very good, but probably even better when young (tasted sample was 2 years old).

A: Caramel and flower. Sweet smelling.

A: 1 finger head. Hazy red, burnt caramel body.

T: Flower, citrus, and caramel dominate. Honey, and a slight sharp pine bitterness, along with sweet graham cracker are subtle.

P: Crisp and bubbly.

O: This was pretty subtle for an IPA. It actually seemed more like an APA. It had the typical balance that Sierra Nevada has mastered. The flavor of flower was front and center, though. Appearance: Pours a pretty clear amber/copper color with a medium off white head. Tons of tiny bubbles stream to the surface. Very pretty beer. Good head retention with a nice amount of lacing. 

Smell: Grapefruit, rubber bands, soap. Not getting much malt. A touch of alcohol smell but no means strong.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with lots of tingly bubbles. 

Taste: Upfront this is all hops. Citrusy in the front with a lingering bitterness calling back to the rubber band smell. The malt comes through at the very end and balances out what could be a hoppy mess without it. As usual, as it warms, the malt is allowed to shine through. 

Overall: It’s a good beer, perhaps a great beer, but it’s not what I want in a winter seasonal. It’s about what you’d expect from Sierra Nevada in terms of taste and aroma. It shows off the hop harvest well, so I guess it’s mission accomplished on that part. If I’m judging it on it just on taste, it’s a probably 8/10, but as a seasonal I’m giving it:

7/10.

12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, bottled on 10/2/2014. Pours slightly hazy deep orange/amber color with a 2 finger dense and rocky off white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, floral, grass, pine, caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of juicy citrus/floral hops and moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, floral, grass, pine, caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Fair amount of pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, floral, grass, light pine, caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of juicy citrus/floral hops and moderate dark/brady malt sweetness; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and fairly creamy/sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent wet hop IPA. All around great complexity and balance of juicy citrus/floral hops and moderate dark/bready malt sweetness; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

I can’t believe I’ve been on here for 10 years and haven’t rated one of my favorite beers that got me into beer in general. This one goes back to when I was 20 and going to my grandparent’s place with my parents. We stopped off at the grocery store and while picking up a few other things there was a huge end cap display for Celebration Ale. I convinced my parent’s to buy me a six pack since it was Christmas themed etc. At that point I’d had maybe six tastes of beer in my life. I still remember sitting by our old Macintosh computer with a 36.6kb modem and looking up random crap on Christmas Eve while sipping on one of those bottles. Bitter and hard at first but such a great beer. Since then I’ve had this beer every year since 2000. I felt this was more true than a random review of this beer. Since then I have hoarded it and done the whole vertical which is insanely dumb with a fresh hop IPA. There is also no Christmas spice in this so I won’t mention that either. Love this beer.

350ml bottle from Mondial de la Bière shop, sans bb. Upfront sweetish, near-medicinal nose of a pine, quince and pineapple rind reduction. Zapach z butelki: Intensywnie tropikalno-żywiczny.
Piana: Ładna, kremowa, drobnopęcherzykowa. Średnio trwała, ładnie oblepia szkło.

Kolor: Jasnomiedziane, trochę zmętnione z pływającymi drobinami.

Zapach: Intensywnie chmielowy. Dominuje mango, trawa, żywica. W tle estrowe poziomki. Po ogrzaniu na pierwszy plan wysuwają się cytrusy.

Smak: Średnia podbudowa ciastkowo-chlebowa. Intensywna chmielowa żywiczność i tropikalne, słodkie owoce.

Tekstura: Pozostawia delikatny osad i umiarkowane ściąganie w jamie ustnej.

Nasycenie: Średnio-wysokie.

Goryczka: Wysoka, ziołowo-grejpfrutowa.

Pijalność: Wysoka.

To piwo okazało się być wyśmienite. Jestem skłonny uwierzyć, że zastosowanie świeżego chmielu daje się odczuć w postaci dużej intensywności aromatu. Dość zdecydowana, ale nie przesadzona słodycz fajnie kontruje zdecydowaną, ale również nie przesadzoną, charakterną goryczkę. Jestem bardzo ciekaw, jak to piwo mogło smakować dwa-trzy miesiące wcześniej, kiedy było ultraświeże. Zdecydowanie spełniło moje oczekiwania.

Served on-tap at Al’s of Hampden into a nonic pint.




A - Pours deep copper orange with a one finger tall white head leaving small streaks of lace down the glass.




S - Smells of sweet caramel malt, pine resin, lightly toasted bread, and citric hops. The hops and malt are well balanced, neither really overpowering the other.




T - Starts off with a nice dose of citric hop bitterness quickly giving way to a mix of sweet caramel malts, fresh baked bread, and some sticky pine resin. It is fairly well balanced but the sweetness is beginning to creep up. The finish is a mix of light sweetness and bitterness, lingering on the pallet for some time.




M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth, slightly sticky, feel that makes it ever so easy to drink.




O - This one remains one of my go to fall beers. The balance of sweetness to bitterness is spot on and it goes down easy. One of the rare IPA’s that gets better with age.

Transfer from BA reveiw on 11-27-12-
 Served on tap in a pint glass

 Appearance – The beer is served an amber color with a two finger white head. The head fades slowly over time to give a decent level of lacing.

Smell – The aroma is heaviest of some biscuit malt, hop, and a spice. The spice is light overall with the hop aromas are of a pine and grapefruit citrus in nature.

 Taste – The taste starts with a bready and roasted flavor. A light sweetness of fruit and caramel is present upfront, which fades as the taste advances further. Spice and hop flavors soon come to the tongue. The spice flavors are the light just as the nose would have suggested and with the loss of some of the sweetness and the new presence of a pine and grapefruit hop flavors, bring a bitter spiced and bready flavor to linger on the tongue at the very end of the taste. 

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is medium in thickness with a carbonation level that is quite average. Not bad for the roasted and spiced flavors of the brew with the moderate carbonation level maintaining a good drinkability.

 Overall – A decent brew. A little bitter for a winter brew, as the bitterness and the spice don’t meld perfectly, but overall not bad.

355 ml bottle as a gift by WheatKing at Q Club in SoHo, Central. Thanks Adam!



Looks: Cloudy hazy amber honey colour with no yeast sediments;Three-quarter finger head and off-white foam which fades in 40 seconds; Excellent sticky lacing with near zero carbonation.



Aroma: Fragrant and sweet Ale malt, with fresh grapefruit, pineapple, floral nectar, honey, caramel, strong pine, resin, strong yeast, light lemon and thin grass.



Taste: Mid to light sweet Ale malt, with grapefruit flesh and zest, light caramel, molasses, strong pine, very light resin, very light alcohol, earth, spices, light biscuits, light lime, bitter hops, and pretty sharp grass.



Body: Medium; Slightly oily and oozy palate.



Mouth Feel: Moderate Ale maltyness with good touches of caramel. Good fruity citrus. Very strong pine but not really resiny. Lack of yeast in bottle means lesser biscuits. The rest are full sharp hoppiness. Pretty well balanced. Gooood!



Hoppiness: Fragrant grapefruit pineapple, floral nectar, strong pine in nose. Quite refreshing citrus zest, strong pine, light resin, earth, spice and light lime in taste. Bitterness is strong, smart and neat, but not as bitter and astringent as typical German Pils. Work well with the light resin for a lasting, mid-to-strong bitter finish.



After Taste: Fairly dry after taste. Hoppy, spicy and delicate to mouth.



Comments: Most American craft IPAs I had were very malty and heavy, not this one: SN really know their stuff and this one is typically strong in pine and fruity aroma, yet the body, taste and hoppiness is lighter without being compromised. Everything is done with a delicate touch, which is well-suited for X’mas but what the hack. An excellent IPA!
